Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Control Tools for Nanoscale Rapid Broadband Viscoelasticity Measurement and Mapping of Soft Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project is to develop a new system identification and control methodology to enable rapid broadband viscoelastic measurements. By mapping soft material responses at multiple scales, the proposed methodology will be realized in nanoscale measurements using scanning probe microscopy (SPM). Currently there are many barriers to measurements of material properties at the nano-, meso-, and macro-scales. They include (i) quasi-static or sinusoidal-oscillatory excitation methods which are either too simple or too slow to rapidly excite the complex behaviors exhibited by soft materials, (ii) hardware dynamics creeping into the measured material properties, particularly when the measurement is at a high frequency, and (iii) significant nonlinearity (such as hysteresis) and system uncertainties. The proposed research will overcome these barriers through the integration of optimal input design for time-varying vescoelastic model identification with the system-inversion theory for rapid tracking-transition switching and large system uncertainties. New iterative control and optimal control techniques will also be developed to allow the high-speed output tracking needed for exerting the optimal excitation input with minimal trade-off of system bandwidth. The outcome of the proposed research is expected to be the measurement of time-varying viscoelastic parameters of soft materials over a frequency range at least 10 fold larger and within a time frame at least 10 fold shorter.

The work will introduce a new paradigm of multi-scale soft material sciences and engineering, and help unravel rate-dependent phenomena like wound healing by linking the macro-/meso- scale measurements to the nano- scale. The realization of the proposed methodology at the nanoscale will improve SPM as the key enabling tool for nanosciences and nanotechnologies, advance our understanding of rapid nanoscale phenomena like dentin collagen dehydration, and accelerate the synthesis and design of nano-/bio- materials including bio-compatible polymers for drug delivery. The PI?s close collaboration with a leading SPM manufacturer will accelerate the technology transfer. The proposed CAREER education activities will promote nanotechnology education in mechanical engineering, through curriculum improvements (including a new course, a teaching module and a web-based SPM simulator), open lab tours for a total of 450 high-school girls by leveraging two well-established outreach programs at ISU, internships for undergraduate women students and high-school science teachers, and industrial internships for graduate students.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The successful outcomes of this CAREER project have result in the creation of advanced control techniques and algorithms for high-speed precision tracking and control of smart actuators such as piezoelectric actuators, and a suite of dynamic system and control tools for high-speed scanning probe microscope (SPM) for nanoscale imaging and mechanical property characterization and quantification of soft materials including polymers and live biological species such as live mammalian cells. The advanced control techniques developed extended the horizon of the stable-inversion and iterative-learning control (ILC) to address challenging control problems in emerging applications, including output tracking with non-periodic tracking-transition switching as occurring in robotic maneuver and nano manipulation, high-speed precision multi-axis trajectory tracking, and high-speed, large-range trajectory tracking of smart actuators with simultaneous hysteresis and dynamics compensation. Specifically, the control techniques developed exploited multi-objective minimization of both input and output constraints, accounted for both high performance and robustness requirements through a data-driven, modeling-free approach in ILC, and extended and broadened the ILC framework to non-repetitive operations for linear systems first, and then hammerstein systems such as smart actuators whose input-output behavior is characterized by a static nonlinear operator followed by a linear time-invariant system. The dynamics and control tools developed for SPM lift up the performance of SPM by over an order of magnitude on the same hardware platform. Particularly, these tools improved the imaging speed of SPM of hard samples by over 15 times, of soft samples by nearly 10 times, and of live mammalian cells by nearly 8 times, all with no loss of imaging quality nor increase of force applied to the sample. These tools also increased the measurement frequency range of nanomechanical measurements using SPM by over one order of magnitude while reducing the measurement time by over one order of magnitude, and achieved high-speed probe-nanomanufacturing with the writing speed in the mm/second region. These results have been published through over twenty-two journal articles published in leading journals, one book chapter, and five articles currently under review/revision, and also resulted in three US. patents (of which two have been issued), and one patent licensing to the leading and largest SPM company. 

 

This CAREER project has also trained five Ph.D. students, of whom four have finished and obtained their Ph.D. degree, including one became a tenure-track Assistant Professor in Iowa State University, three MS. students, six undergraduate students, and four visiting scholars. 

 


Last Modified: 12/11/2015
Modified by: Qingze Zou

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The successful outcomes of this CAREER project have result in the creation of advanced control techniques and algorithms for high-speed precision tracking and control of smart actuators such as piezoelectric actuators, and a suite of dynamic system and control tools for high-speed scanning probe microscope (SPM) for nanoscale imaging and mechanical property characterization and quantification of soft materials including polymers and live biological species such as live mammalian cells. The advanced control techniques developed extended the horizon of the stable-inversion and iterative-learning control (ILC) to address challenging control problems in emerging applications, including output tracking with non-periodic tracking-transition switching as occurring in robotic maneuver and nano manipulation, high-speed precision multi-axis trajectory tracking, and high-speed, large-range trajectory tracking of smart actuators with simultaneous hysteresis and dynamics compensation. Specifically, the control techniques developed exploited multi-objective minimization of both input and output constraints, accounted for both high performance and robustness requirements through a data-driven, modeling-free approach in ILC, and extended and broadened the ILC framework to non-repetitive operations for linear systems first, and then hammerstein systems such as smart actuators whose input-output behavior is characterized by a static nonlinear operator followed by a linear time-invariant system. The dynamics and control tools developed for SPM lift up the performance of SPM by over an order of magnitude on the same hardware platform. Particularly, these tools improved the imaging speed of SPM of hard samples by over 15 times, of soft samples by nearly 10 times, and of live mammalian cells by nearly 8 times, all with no loss of imaging quality nor increase of force applied to the sample. These tools also increased the measurement frequency range of nanomechanical measurements using SPM by over one order of magnitude while reducing the measurement time by over one order of magnitude, and achieved high-speed probe-nanomanufacturing with the writing speed in the mm/second region. These results have been published through over twenty-two journal articles published in leading journals, one book chapter, and five articles currently under review/revision, and also resulted in three US. patents (of which two have been issued), and one patent licensing to the leading and largest SPM company. This CAREER project has also trained five Ph.D. students, of whom four have finished and obtained their Ph.D. degree, including one became a tenure-track Assistant Professor in Iowa State University, three MS. students, six undergraduate students, and four visiting scholars.
